WGS.documentation: Whole Genome Sequencing - random sequencing of the whole genome (see pubmed 10731132 for details)

WGA.documentation: Whole Genome Amplification followed by random sequencing. (see pubmed 1631067,8962113 for details)

WXS.documentation: Random sequencing of exonic regions selected from the genome. (see pubmed 20111037 for details)

RNA-Seq.documentation: Random sequencing of whole transcriptome, also known as Whole Transcriptome Shotgun Sequencing, or WTSS). (see    pubmed 18611170 for details)

snRNA-seq.documentation: Single nucleus RNA sequencing is a method for profiling gene expression in cells which are difficult to isolate.

miRNA-Seq.documentation: Micro RNA sequencing strategy designed to capture post-transcriptional RNA elements and include non-coding    functional elements. (see pubmed 21787409 for details)

ncRNA-Seq.documentation: Capture of other non-coding RNA types, including post-translation modification types such as snRNA (small    nuclear RNA) or snoRNA (small nucleolar RNA), or expression regulation types such as siRNA (small interfering RNA) or    piRNA/piwi/RNA (piwi-interacting RNA).

EST.documentation: Single pass sequencing of cDNA templates

Hi-C.documentation: Chromosome Conformation Capture technique where a biotin-labeled nucleotide is incorporated at the ligation junction, enabling selective purification of chimeric DNA ligation junctions followed by deep sequencing.

ATAC-seq.documentation: Assay for Transposase-Accessible Chromatin (ATAC) strategy is used to study genome-wide chromatin accessibility. alternative method to DNase-seq that uses an engineered Tn5 transposase to cleave DNA and to integrate primer DNA sequences into the cleaved genomic DNA.

WCS.documentation: Random sequencing of a whole chromosome or other replicon isolated from a genome.

POOLCLONE.documentation: Shotgun of pooled clones (usually BACs and Fosmids).

AMPLICON.documentation: Sequencing of overlapping or distinct PCR or RT-PCR products. For example, metagenomic community profiling    using SSU rRNA .

FINISHING.documentation: Sequencing intended to finish (close) gaps in existing coverage.

ChIP-Seq.documentation: ChIP-seq, Chromatin ImmunoPrecipitation, reveals binding sites of specific proteins, typically transcription factors (TFs) using antibodies to extract DNA fragments bound to the target protein.

MNase-Seq.documentation: Identifies well-positioned nucleosomes. uses Micrococcal Nuclease (MNase) is an endo-exonuclease that processively digests DNA until an obstruction, such as a nucleosome, is reached.

DNase-Hypersensitivity.documentation: Sequencing of hypersensitive sites, or segments of open chromatin that are more readily cleaved by DNaseI.

Bisulfite-Seq.documentation: MethylC-seq. Sequencing following treatment of DNA with bisulfite to convert cytosine residues to uracil    depending on methylation status.

Tn-Seq.documentation: Quantitatively determine fitness of bacterial genes based on how many times a purposely seeded transposon gets    inserted into each gene of a colony after some time.

VALIDATION.documentation: CGHub special request: Independent experiment to re-evaluate putative variants.

FAIRE-seq.documentation: Formaldehyde Assisted Isolation of Regulatory Elements. Reveals regions of open chromatin.

SELEX.documentation: Systematic Evolution of Ligands by Exponential enrichment

RIP-Seq.documentation: Direct sequencing of RNA immunoprecipitates (includes CLIP-Seq, HITS-CLIP and PAR-CLIP).

ChIA-PET.documentation: Direct sequencing of proximity-ligated chromatin immunoprecipitates.

Synthetic-Long-Read.documentation: binning and barcoding of large DNA fragments to facilitate assembly of the fragment

Targeted-Capture.documentation: Enrichment of a targeted subset of loci.

ChM-Seq.documentation: ChIPmentation combines chromatin immunoprecipitation with sequencing library preparation by Tn5 transposase (see pubmed 26280331 for details)

GBS.documentation: Genotyping by sequencing is a method to discover single nucleotide polymorphisms for genotyping studies.

Ribo-Seq.documentation: Ribosome profiling (also named ribosome footprinting) that uses specialized messenger RNA (mRNA) sequencing to determine which mRNAs are being actively translated. It produces a
of all the ribosomes active in a cell at a particular moment, known as a translatome.
